a_0.formal problem:
datatype Color = Color1 | Color2 | Color3 | Color4 | Color5 | Color6 | Color7 | Color8 | Color9

datatype Square = A | B | C | D | E | F | G | H | I

fun paint :: "Square \<Rightarrow> Color" where
"paint A = Color1" |
"paint B = Color2" |
"paint C = Color1" |
"paint D = Color2" |
"paint E = Color3" |
"paint F = Color2" |
"paint G = Color1" |
"paint H = Color2" |
"paint I = Color1"

theorem max_colors:
assumes h0 : "paint A = paint I \<and> paint B = paint H \<and> paint C = paint G \<and> paint D = paint F"
and h1 : "paint A = paint C \<and> paint D = paint B \<and> paint E = paint E \<and> paint F = paint H \<and> paint G = paint I"
shows  "\<exists> c1 c2 c3. (\<forall> s. paint s = c1 \<or> paint s = c2 \<or> paint s = c3)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each square of the three by three grid is painted so that the whole picture has at least the two lines of symmetry indicated. Each grid square is painted one solid color. What is the maximum number of colors that could have been used? [asy]size(100);
draw((0,0)--(0,3)--(3,3)--(3,0)--cycle);
draw((1,0)--(1,3));
draw((2,0)--(2,3));
draw((0,1)--(3,1));
draw((0,2)--(3,2));
draw((-0.2,-0.2)--(3.2,3.2),dashed);
dot((0,0));dot((3,3)); dot((1.5,0)); dot((1.5,3));
draw((1.5,-0.3)--(1.5,3.3), dashed);
[/asy] The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 The color of the center square is unrestricted, so we can call that color 1. If, without loss of generality, we assign color 2 to the top left corner, the vertical line of symmetry forces the top right square to also be color 2, and the diagonal line of symmetry forces the bottom right square to be color 2, which then, by the vertical line of symmetry, forces the bottom left square to be color 2.
 Finally, if, without loss of generality, we assign color 3 to the top middle square, the diagonal line of symmetry forces the right middle square to be color 3, which then, by the vertical line of symmetry, forces the left middle square to be color 3, and this then forces the bottom middle square to also be color 3, by the diagonal line of symmetry.
 Thus, at most $\boxed{3}$ colors may be used.
 *)

datatype Color = Color1 | Color2 | Color3 | Color4 | Color5 | Color6 | Color7 | Color8 | Color9

datatype Square = A | B | C | D | E | F | G | H | I

fun paint :: "Square \<Rightarrow> Color" where
"paint A = Color1" |
"paint B = Color2" |
"paint C = Color1" |
"paint D = Color2" |
"paint E = Color3" |
"paint F = Color2" |
"paint G = Color1" |
"paint H = Color2" |
"paint I = Color1"

theorem max_colors:
assumes h0 : "paint A = paint I \<and> paint B = paint H \<and> paint C = paint G \<and> paint D = paint F"
and h1 : "paint A = paint C \<and> paint D = paint B \<and> paint E = paint E \<and> paint F = paint H \<and> paint G = paint I"
shows  "\<exists> c1 c2 c3. (\<forall> s. paint s = c1 \<or> paint s = c2 \<or> paint s = c3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
There are 9 squares, labeled A to I, and 9 colors, labeled Color1 to Color9. Each square is painted with one of the colors according to the following rules:

1. A is painted with Color1
2. B is painted with Color2
3. C is painted with Color1
4. D is painted with Color2
5. E is painted with Color3
6. F is painted with Color2
7. G is painted with Color1
8. H is painted with Color2
9. I is painted with Color1

Now, consider two additional conditions:

1. A and I have the same color, B and H have the same color, C and G have the same color, and D and F have the same color.
2. A and C have the same color, D and B have the same color, E has the same color, F and H have the same color, and G and I have the same color.

Is it possible to find three colors, c1, c2, and c3, such that every square is painted with one of these three colors?

a_3.formal problem:
theorem max_colors_of_symmetric_grid:
fixes num_colors :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_colors = (GREATEST n. \<exists> c1 c2 c3. c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> c1 \<noteq> c3 \<and> c2 \<noteq> c3 \<and> symmetric_coloring c1 c2 c3)"
shows  "num_colors = 3"
where "symmetric_coloring c1 c2 c3 \<equiv> (\<forall> i j. (1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 3) \<and> (1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 3) \<longrightarrow> (grid i j = c1 \<or> grid i j = c2 \<or> grid i j = c3))"
and "grid i j = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then c1 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then c2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then c1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then c2 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then c3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then c2 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then c1 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then c2 else c1)"

Find the maximum number of colors used in this grid. The final answer is 3.

a_2_deepseek.formal problem:
definition grid :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> (nat \<times> nat) set" where
"grid n m = {(i, j) | i j. i \<in> {0..<n} \<and> j \<in> {0..<m}}"

definition symmetric :: "((nat \<times> nat) set \<Rightarrow> bool) \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"symmetric f = (f {(0,0),(0,1),(0,2),(1,0),(1,1),(1,2),(2,0),(2,1),(2,2)} \<and>
 f {(0,0),(0,1),(0,2),(1,0),(1,1),(1,2),(2,0),(2,1),(2,2)} =
 f {(0,0),(1,0),(2,0),(0,1),(1,1),(2,1),(0,2),(1,2),(2,2)})"

lemma max_colors:
fixes paint :: "(nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "symmetric (\<lambda> S. paint (SOME p. p \<in> S))"
shows "card {c. \<exists> p \<in> grid 3 3. paint p = c} \<le> 3"

a_4_deepseek.formal problem:
datatype Color = Red | Blue | Green | Yellow | ...

type_synonym Grid = "Color list list"

definition has_horizontal_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_horizontal_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_horizontal c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition has_vertical_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_vertical_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_vertical c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition has_diagonal_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_diagonal_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_diagonal c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition valid_painting :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"valid_painting G = (has_horizontal_symmetry G \<and> has_vertical_symmetry G \<and> has_diagonal_symmetry G)"

theorem max_colors_in_valid_painting:
"card (set (concat G)) \<le> 3" if "valid_painting G" for G :: Grid
using that

datatype Color = Red | Blue | Green | Yellow | ...

type_synonym Grid = "Color list list"

definition has_horizontal_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_horizontal_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_horizontal c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition has_vertical_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_vertical_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_vertical c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition has_diagonal_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_diagonal_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_diagonal c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition valid_painting :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"valid_painting G = (has_horizontal_symmetry G \<and> has_vertical_symmetry G \<and> has_diagonal_symmetry G)"

theorem max_colors_in_valid_painting:
"card (set (concat G)) \<le> 3" if "valid_painting G" for G :: Grid

datatype Color = Color1 | Color2 | Color3 | Color4 | Color5 | Color6 | Color7 | Color8 | Color9

datatype Square = A | B | C | D | E | F | G | H | I

fun paint :: "Square \<Rightarrow> Color" where
"paint A = Color1" |
"paint B = Color2" |
"paint C = Color1" |
"paint D = Color2" |
"paint E = Color3" |
"paint F = Color2" |
"paint G = Color1" |
"paint H = Color2" |
"paint I = Color1"

theorem max_colors:
assumes h0 : "paint A = paint I \<and> paint B = paint H \<and> paint C = paint G \<and> paint D = paint F"
and h1 : "paint A = paint C \<and> paint D = paint B \<and> paint E = paint E \<and> paint F = paint H \<and> paint G = paint I"
shows  "\<exists> c1 c2 c3. (\<forall> s. paint s = c1 \<or> paint s = c2 \<or> paint s = c3)"
a_0_solve_direct.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each square of the three by three grid is painted so that the whole picture has at least the two lines of symmetry indicated. Each grid square is painted one solid color. What is the maximum number of colors that could have been used? [asy]size(100);
draw((0,0)--(0,3)--(3,3)--(3,0)--cycle);
draw((1,0)--(1,3));
draw((2,0)--(2,3));
draw((0,1)--(3,1));
draw((0,2)--(3,2));
draw((-0.2,-0.2)--(3.2,3.2),dashed);
dot((0,0));dot((3,3)); dot((1.5,0)); dot((1.5,3));
draw((1.5,-0.3)--(1.5,3.3), dashed);
[/asy] The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 The color of the center square is unrestricted, so we can call that color 1. If, without loss of generality, we assign color 2 to the top left corner, the vertical line of symmetry forces the top right square to also be color 2, and the diagonal line of symmetry forces the bottom right square to be color 2, which then, by the vertical line of symmetry, forces the bottom left square to be color 2.
 Finally, if, without loss of generality, we assign color 3 to the top middle square, the diagonal line of symmetry forces the right middle square to be color 3, which then, by the vertical line of symmetry, forces the left middle square to be color 3, and this then forces the bottom middle square to also be color 3, by the diagonal line of symmetry.
 Thus, at most $\boxed{3}$ colors may be used.
 *)

datatype Color = Color1 | Color2 | Color3 | Color4 | Color5 | Color6 | Color7 | Color8 | Color9

datatype Square = A | B | C | D | E | F | G | H | I

fun paint :: "Square \<Rightarrow> Color" where
"paint A = Color1" |
"paint B = Color2" |
"paint C = Color1" |
"paint D = Color2" |
"paint E = Color3" |
"paint F = Color2" |
"paint G = Color1" |
"paint H = Color2" |
"paint I = Color1"

theorem max_colors:
assumes h0 : "paint A = paint I \<and> paint B = paint H \<and> paint C = paint G \<and> paint D = paint F"
and h1 : "paint A = paint C \<and> paint D = paint B \<and> paint E = paint E \<and> paint F = paint H \<and> paint G = paint I"
shows  "\<exists> c1 c2 c3. (\<forall> s. paint s = c1 \<or> paint s = c2 \<or> paint s = c3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_3_solve_direct.formal problem:
theorem max_colors_of_symmetric_grid:
fixes num_colors :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_colors = (GREATEST n. \<exists> c1 c2 c3. c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> c1 \<noteq> c3 \<and> c2 \<noteq> c3 \<and> symmetric_coloring c1 c2 c3)"
shows  "num_colors = 3"
where "symmetric_coloring c1 c2 c3 \<equiv> (\<forall> i j. (1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 3) \<and> (1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 3) \<longrightarrow> (grid i j = c1 \<or> grid i j = c2 \<or> grid i j = c3))"
and "grid i j = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then c1 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then c2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then c1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then c2 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then c3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then c2 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then c1 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then c2 else c1)"

definition grid :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> (nat \<times> nat) set" where
"grid n m = {(i, j) | i j. i \<in> {0..<n} \<and> j \<in> {0..<m}}"

definition symmetric :: "((nat \<times> nat) set \<Rightarrow> bool) \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"symmetric f = (f {(0,0),(0,1),(0,2),(1,0),(1,1),(1,2),(2,0),(2,1),(2,2)} \<and>
 f {(0,0),(0,1),(0,2),(1,0),(1,1),(1,2),(2,0),(2,1),(2,2)} =
 f {(0,0),(1,0),(2,0),(0,1),(1,1),(2,1),(0,2),(1,2),(2,2)})"

lemma max_colors:
fixes paint :: "(nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "symmetric (\<lambda> S. paint (SOME p. p \<in> S))"
shows "card {c. \<exists> p \<in> grid 3 3. paint p = c} \<le> 3"

a_4_deepseek_solve_direct.formal problem:
datatype Color = Red | Blue | Green | Yellow | ...

type_synonym Grid = "Color list list"

definition has_horizontal_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_horizontal_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_horizontal c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition has_vertical_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_vertical_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_vertical c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition has_diagonal_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_diagonal_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_diagonal c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition valid_painting :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"valid_painting G = (has_horizontal_symmetry G \<and> has_vertical_symmetry G \<and> has_diagonal_symmetry G)"

theorem max_colors_in_valid_painting:
"card (set (concat G)) \<le> 3" if "valid_painting G" for G :: Grid
using that

 ### Proof
 The color of the center square is unrestricted, so we can call that color 1. If, without loss of generality, we assign color 2 to the top left corner, the vertical line of symmetry forces the top right square to also be color 2, and the diagonal line of symmetry forces the bottom right square to be color 2, which then, by the vertical line of symmetry, forces the bottom left square to be color 2.
Finally, if, without loss of generality, we assign color 3 to the top middle square, the diagonal line of symmetry forces the right middle square to be color 3, which then, by the vertical line of symmetry, forces the left middle square to be color 3, and this then forces the bottom middle square to also be color 3, by the diagonal line of symmetry.
Thus, at most $\boxed{3}$ colors may be used.

datatype Color = Red | Blue | Green | Yellow | ...

type_synonym Grid = "Color list list"

definition has_horizontal_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_horizontal_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_horizontal c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition has_vertical_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_vertical_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_vertical c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition has_diagonal_symmetry :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"has_diagonal_symmetry G = (\<forall>i<3. G ! i = map (\<lambda>c. reflect_diagonal c) (G ! (2 - i)))"

definition valid_painting :: "Grid \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"valid_painting G = (has_horizontal_symmetry G \<and> has_vertical_symmetry G \<and> has_diagonal_symmetry G)"

theorem max_colors_in_valid_painting:
"card (set (concat G)) \<le> 3" if "valid_painting G" for G :: Grid
using that
